I’ve bought dickies jeans for many years. My last pic have was a very poor one. I bought 10 pairs of dickies jeans before that were made in Mexico and lasted me a few years. A few months ago I bought another 10 pairs but these are from Bangladesh. The material feels much thinner, the pockets are smaller and not quite as deep. I’ve worn the same 6 or 7 pair for since I got them and I have one pair the tire just to the left of the fly away from the stitching and another pair that has torn at the stitching at the left of the fly and also at the top left corner of the right rear pocket (where I carry my phone). If memory serves me correctly I paid $34 or $37 a pair for these jeans. I am extremely disappointed and dissatisfied with these jeans a will pay a little extra to buy them locally instead of online. I do not recommend the Bangladesh made dickies jeans or any other product if this is the quality standard from Bangladeshi.

My boyfriend is an electrician and I buy him Dickies all the time because of their durability. He likes the Carpenter style so I saw these and figured a slight change in style would do him good! I usually order him the regular carpenter pants but decided to try the straight-fit carpenter pants to my chagrin. He got them for Christmas and they lasted just two months. While working, he crouched down and the entire crotch region ripped right out of them. Though I found it hilarious, he was not stoked to wrap the nether regions of the pants in duct tape to finish his shift. I realized the material was quite a bit thinner than the other ones I ordered for him...a lot thinner. I would never think that changing from regular to straight-leg would mean cheaper quality, but alas it has. If you are looking for sturdy work carpenter jeans, forgo these and order the regular Dickies....NOT the straight-fit, unless you want to duct tape the crotch of your pants closed while working.

评论概述: Good design buuut the material is thinner than expected
评论详情: I generally swear by Carhartt, Ben Davis, and Dickies as major players in work wear makers.  All of their jeans have been rugged and the material was thick and sometimes a bit stiff at first wear.  They soften after a break in period, but they last for more than one year.  They take a lickin' and keep on kickin.'  Lately I have noticed that many manufacturers of work wear (especially those who outsourced aggressively) are using thinner less expensive material that wears out much sooner than my old "work wear" clothing. Unfortunately these jeans seem to be products of the aggressive outsourcing strategy that relies on brand name to justify price point.  They're OK , buuut.... will not last as long as my older Dickies jeans.  Nice design, but fashion models don't work in construction.
Very nice and good Quality

Front pockets have been reduced in size by half.  Cellphone sticks out.  When I cross my legs change nearly rolls out. Do not like this change at all.  Will buy from retail next time so I can check the pockets first.  May try other brands in the meantime.
